questions.title: Passage Ⅰ
questions.article:
As a polyol (a natural sweetener) dissolves in water, the temperature of the solution that forms changes over time. Table 1 shows the change in temperature of each of 4 polyol solutions over the first 6 sec of formation. Each solution was formed by dissolving 0. 5 kg of a polyol (either xylitol, maltitol, erythritol, or isomalt) in 1 L of water.


The sweetness of a food containing a polyol is related to the polyol's solubility (maximum percent by mass of the polyol that can dissolve in water kept at a constant temperature). Table 2 shows, for each of the 4 polyols, the relative sweetness and the solubility in water at 4 temperatures.


Tables adapted from H. Mitchell,ed. , Sweeteners and Sugar Alter-natives in Food Technology. ©2006 by Blackwell Publishing.
questions.question: 1. Which of the polyols listed in Table 2 is least soluble in water at 40℃?

questions.question: 6. The dissolving of a polyol in water requires energy. Based on Table 1, the dissolving of which polyol over the 6 sec period required the most energy?

choices.A: Xylitol; the temperature change was less for xylitol than for any of the other polyols.
choices.B: Xylitol; the temperature change was greater for xylitol than for any of the other polyols.
choices.C: Isomalt; the temperature change was less for isomalt than for any of the other polyols.
choices.D: Isomalt; the temperature change was greater for isomalt than for any of the other polyols.

questions.title: Passage Ⅱ
questions.article:
When a 13-lined ground squirrel (a mammal) hibernates, it does not eat, and it alternates between periods of torpor (characterized by a reduced rate of metabolism, low body temperature, and little movement) and active bouts (characterized by a normal rate of metabolism, normal body temperature, and normal movement). Figure 1 shows the body temperature of a 13-lined ground squirrel during 12 consecutive months, including several months of hibernation. Figure 2 shows the average total blood cholesterol of a group of 13-lined ground squirrels at various times during the same 12 months.



Figures adapted from Jessica P. Otis et al., "Cholesterol and Lipoprotein Dynamics in a Hibernating Mammal."@2011 by Otis et al.
questions.question: 7. According to Figure 1, when the 13-lined ground squirrel was NOT hibernating, its average body temperature was approximately:

questions.question: 9. Which of the following statements about hibernation and total blood cholesterol is best supported by Figure 2? On average, the 13-lined ground squirrels total blood cholesterol was:

choices.A: above 300 mg/dL when the squirrels were hibernating and below 300 mg/dL when the squirrels were not hibernating.
choices.B: below 300 mg/dL when the squirrels were hibernating and above 300 mg/dL when the squirrels were not hibernating.
choices.C: above 500 mg/dL when the squirrels were hibernating and below 500 mg/dL when the squirrels were not hibernating.
choices.D: below 500 mg/dL when the squirrels were hibernating and above 500 mg/dL when the squirrels were not hibernating.

questions.question: 10. Do 13-lined ground squirrels more likely consume O2 at a greater rate during periods of torpor or during active bouts?

choices.A: Periods of torpor; the rate of metabolism is higher during periods of torpor than during active bouts.
choices.B: Periods of torpor; the rate of metabolism is lower during periods of torpor than during active bouts.
choices.C: Active bouts; the rate of metabolism is higher during active bouts than during periods of torpor.
choices.D: Active bouts; the rate of metabolism is lower during active bouts than during periods of torpor.

questions.question: 12. Consider the blood samples having an average total cholesterol of 420 mg/dL, as shown in Figure 2. Based on Figure 1, were those blood samples collected when the 13-lined ground squirrels were hibernating?

choices.A: Yes; the samples were collected while the squirrels were in an active bout during hibernation.
choices.B: Yes; the samples were collected while the squirrels were in a period of torpor during hibernation.
choices.C: No; the samples were collected while the squirrels were in an active bout, which does not occur during hibernation.
choices.D: No; the samples were collected while the squirrels were in a period of torpor, which does not occur during hibernation.

questions.title: Passage Ⅲ
questions.article:
A study examined the production and consumption of methane (CH4) by soil bacteria in 4 areas of a particular forest: an area of healthy black spruce trees, an area of burned black spruce trees, an area of healthy jack pine trees, and an area of burned jack pine trees.

Study
On May 15, 4 identical soil gas collection cylinders were placed in the forest, one in each area. Each cylinder had an open end and a closed end; its open end was pushed into the soil, and then its aboveground surface was covered with shiny foil (see Figure 1). That same day, a gas sample was taken from each cylinder by inserting the needle of a50 cm3 syringe into the closed end (through an airtight seal). The CH4 content of each gas sample was determined. Likewise, on the 15th day of June, July, August, and September, a gas sample was taken from each cylinder and its CH4 content was determined.


The difference in the CH4 contents of consecutive samples (for example, the samples taken on May 15 and June 15) from a cylinder indicated whether there had been a net production of CH4 (more CH4 had been produced than consumed) or a net consumption of CH4 (more CH4 had been consumed than produced) in the area over the month between the 2 sampling dates. From these differences, the average rate of CH4 production or consumption was calculated, in milligrams per square meter per day (mg/m2/day), for each area over each month (see Figure 2).


Figure 2 adapted from Sami Ullah et al. , "Greenhouse Gas Fluxes from Boreal Forest Soils during the Snow-Free Period in Quebec, Canada." ©2009 by NRC Research Press.
questions.question: 13. According to the results of the study, in either area of jack pine trees, CH4 was consumed at the greatest rate over the month that ended on:

questions.question: 14.  Over which 2 months was there a net production of CH4 in both areas of black spruce trees?

choices.A: The month ending on June 15 and the month ending on July 15
choices.B: The month ending on June 15 and the month ending on August 15
choices.C: The month ending on July 15 and the month ending on September 15
choices.D: The month ending on August 15 and the month ending on September 15

questions.question: 17. Consider the unit of measurement in Figure 2 for the average rate of CH4 production or consumption. What quantity is represented by "mg," and what quantity is represented by "m2"？                 mg                                            m2

choices.A: mass of CH4                           area of soil
choices.B: mass of soil                           area of soil
choices.C: density of CH4                    volume of cylinder
choices.D: density of air                       volume of cylinder

choices.D: The open end of the cylinder

questions.question: 19.  Let x represent the CH4 content of the gas inside a cylinder on May 15, and let y represent the CH4 content of the gas inside the cylinder on June 15. Based on Figure 2, in the area of burned jack pine trees, was x > y or was x < y ?

choices.A: x > y, because there was a net production of CH4 from May 15 to June 15 in that area.
choices.B: x > y, because there was a net consumption of CH4 from May 15 to June 15 in that area.
choices.C: x < y, because there was a net production of CH4 from May 15 to June 15 in that area.
choices.D: x < y, because there was a net consumption of CH4 from May 15 to June 15 in that area.

questions.title: Passage Ⅳ
questions.article:
Acetates are compounds with the chemical formula CH3CO2R, where R is an unreactive chain of carbon and hydrogen atoms. In the presence of a catalyst, acetates can undergo hydrolysis (reaction with H2O) to produce both acetic acid (CH3CO2H) and an alcohol (ROH):


The rate at which hydrolysis occurs is proportional to the rate constant, k, of the reaction.

Three experiments were done to determine k for the hydrolysis of various acetates. In each trial, Steps 1-3 were performed:

1. Three mL of aqueous 1.0 mole/liter (mol/L) potassium hydroxide (the catalyst) and 80 mL of a solvent were combined.

2. The solution was brought to a particular temperature, and then 0. 2 mL of an acetate was added to the solution.

3. The progress of the hydrolysis reaction at the particular temperature was monitored over time to determine k, measured in.

Experiment 1
In Trials 1-6, k for each of 6 acetates with different R chains (groups) was determined using a solvent composed of 37% acetone and 63% H2O, by volume, at 25C. See Table 1.


Experiment 2
In Trials 7-10, Trials 1-4 of Experiment1 were repeated, except with a solvent composed of 70% acetone and 30% H2O by volume. See Table 2.


Experiment 3
In Trials 11-13, Trial 8 of Experiment 2 was repeated at 3 other temperatures: 20℃, 35℃, and 45°C. In Trials 14-16, Trial 9 was repeated at those 3 temperatures. In Trials 17-19, Trial 10 was repeated at those 3 temperatures. See Table 3.


Tables adapted from S. Hilal, "Estimation of Hydrolysis Rate Constants of Carboxylic Acid Ester and Phosphate Ester Compounds in Aqueous Systems from Molecular Structure by SPARC." U. S. Environmental Protection Agency. 2006.
questions.question: 20. According to the results of Experiment 1, from acetate to acetate, as the number of C atoms in the R group increased, the value of k:

questions.question: 22. Which of the following pieces of laboratory equipment was most likely used in Step 1 of the experimental procedure?

questions.title: Passage Ⅳ
questions.article:
Acetates are compounds with the chemical formula CH3CO2R, where R is an unreactive chain of carbon and hydrogen atoms. In the presence of a catalyst, acetates can undergo hydrolysis (reaction with H2O) to produce both acetic acid (CH3CO2H) and an alcohol (ROH):


The rate at which hydrolysis occurs is proportional to the rate constant, k, of the reaction.

Three experiments were done to determine k for the hydrolysis of various acetates. In each trial, Steps 1-3 were performed:

1. Three mL of aqueous 1.0 mole/liter (mol/L) potassium hydroxide (the catalyst) and 80 mL of a solvent were combined.

2. The solution was brought to a particular temperature, and then 0. 2 mL of an acetate was added to the solution.

3. The progress of the hydrolysis reaction at the particular temperature was monitored over time to determine k, measured in.

Experiment 1
In Trials 1-6, k for each of 6 acetates with different R chains (groups) was determined using a solvent composed of 37% acetone and 63% H2O, by volume, at 25C. See Table 1.


Experiment 2
In Trials 7-10, Trials 1-4 of Experiment1 were repeated, except with a solvent composed of 70% acetone and 30% H2O by volume. See Table 2.


Experiment 3
In Trials 11-13, Trial 8 of Experiment 2 was repeated at 3 other temperatures: 20℃, 35℃, and 45°C. In Trials 14-16, Trial 9 was repeated at those 3 temperatures. In Trials 17-19, Trial 10 was repeated at those 3 temperatures. See Table 3.


Tables adapted from S. Hilal, "Estimation of Hydrolysis Rate Constants of Carboxylic Acid Ester and Phosphate Ester Compounds in Aqueous Systems from Molecular Structure by SPARC." U. S. Environmental Protection Agency. 2006.
questions.question: 23. Suppose that in Experiment 3 the acetate with the R group CH3(CH2)2 had been hydrolyzed at 32°C. At that temperature, the value of k would most likely have been:

questions.question: 25. Can it be determined on the basis of Experiment 2 whether the rate constant depends on the temperature of the reaction solution?

choices.A: Yes, because in Experiment 2, the temperature of the reaction solution was varied.
choices.B: Yes, because in Experiment 2, the temperature of the reaction solution was held constant.
choices.C: No, because in Experiment 2, the temperature of the reaction solution was varied.
choices.D: No, because in Experiment 2, the temperature of the reaction solution was held constant.

questions.question: 26. The dielectric constant (ε) of a substance is a measure of the polarity of the substance; the greater the value of ε, the greater the polarity. If the e of acetone is 21 and the ε of H2O is 80, was the solvent used in Experiment 1 less polar or more polar than the solvent used in Experiment 2?

choices.A: Less polar, because the solvent used in Experiment I contained a higher percent of acetone than did the solvent in Experiment 2.
choices.B: Less polar, because the solvent used in Experiment I contained a higher percent of H2O than did the solvent in Experiment 2.
choices.C: More polar, because the solvent used in Experiment I contained a higher percent of acetone than did the solvent in Experiment 2.
choices.D: More polar, because the solvent used in Experiment I contained a higher percent of H2O than did the solvent in Experiment 2.

questions.title: Passage Ⅴ
questions.article:
When attacked by predators, tadpoles secrete Protein F into their surroundings. A scientist conducted 2 experiments with Protein F: one to examine how the activity of tadpoles changes immediately after a period of exposure to Protein F and the other to examine how depriving tadpoles of food affects their activity during a subsequent period of exposure to Protein F.

Experiment 1
One hundred tadpoles were equally divided into 4 groups (Groups 1-4). The groups were separately placed into equal volumes of water having the Protein F concentrations shown in Table 1.

After 2 hr, the groups were separately placed into equal volumes of pure water. The tadpole activity of each group was then monitored at regular intervals over the next 90 min. (The tadpole activity of a group was the number of tadpoles that were swimming during a 5 sec observation period. ) The results are shown in Figure 1.


Figure 1 adapted from Michaol E. Fraker, "The Dynamics of Predation Risk Assessment: Responses of Anuran Larvae to Chemical Cues of Predators." @2008 by British Ecological Society.

Experiment 2
Two hundred tadpoles were equally divided into 4 groups (Groups 5-8), and the groups were separately placed into equal volumes of pure water. Each group was deprived of food for a specific length of time: Group 5 for 24 hr, Group 6 for I hr, Group 7 for 12 hr, and Group 8 for 24 hr. At the end of their respective deprivation periods, the groups were separately placed into equal volumes of water having the Protein F concentrations shown in Table 2.

The tadpole activity of each group was then monitored at regular intervals over the next 150 min (see Figure 2).


Figure 2 adapted trom Michael E. Fraker, "Risk Assessment and Anti-Predator Behavior of Wood Frog (Rana sylvatica) Tadpoles: A Comparison with Green Frog (Rana clamitans) Tadpoles." @2010 by Society for the Study of Amphibians and Reptiles.
questions.question: 27. Which of the following groups was most likely intended to serve as a control for the effect of Protein F on tadpole activity?

choices.A: The number of tadpoles in each group was greater in Experiment 1 than in Experiment 2.
choices.B: The number of tadpoles in each group was greater in Experiment 2 than in Experiment 1.
choices.C: The groups of tadpoles were placed into equal volumes of water in Experiment 1 but not in Experiment 2.
choices.D: The groups of tadpoles were placed into equal volumes of water in Experiment 2 but not in Experiment 1.

questions.question: 32. Consider the statement "When the tadpoles were in the presence of Protein F, the activity of the tadpoles that were more hungry increased faster than did the activity of the tadpoles that were less hungry." Do the results of Experiment 2 support this statement ?

choices.A: Yes; as the length of time that tadpoles were deprived of food increased, the rate of increase in the number of swimming tadpoles increased.
choices.B: Yes; as the length of time that tadpoles were deprived of food increased, the rate of increase in the number of swimming tadpoles decreased.
choices.C: No; as the length of time that tadpoles were deprived of food increased, the rate of increase in the number of swimming tadpoles increased.
choices.D: No; as the length of time that tadpoles were deprived of food increased, the rate of increase in the number of swimming tadpoles decreased.

questions.question: 33. Consider the statement "The activity of the tadpoles that had been exposed to 300 pM of Protein F increased faster than did the activity of the tadpoles that had been exposed to 100 pM of Protein F." Do the results of Experiment 1 support this statement ?

choices.A: Yes; the rate at which tadpole activity increased was greater for Group I than it was for Group 3.
choices.B: Yes; the rate at which tadpole activity increased was greater for Group 4 than it was for Group 2.
choices.C: No; the rate at which tadpole activity increased was greater for Group 3 than it was for Group 1.
choices.D: No; the rate at which tadpole activity increased was greater for Group 2 than it was for Group 4.

questions.title: Passage Ⅵ
questions.article:
A physics teacher asked 3 students to predict the changes, if any, to light's energy, E; frequency, f(the number of wave peaks passing a given point each second); wavelength, λ (the distance between adjacent peaks of a light wave); and speed, vL, that occur when light travels from a vacuum into clear glass and then from the glass back into the vacuum. The teacher asked the students tobase their predictions on one or both of the following equations:

E = h x f, where h always has the same value

vL = f x λ

Student 1
When light enters the glass, f and E are unchanged. This occurs because light loses no energy when it collides with atoms of the glass. However, vL becomes less than c (the speed of light in a vacuum, 3 x 108 m/sec) due to these collisions, so λ must also decrease.

As the light leaves the glass, both f and E are still unchanged. But upon reentering the vacuum, vL once again becomes c, so λ must increase.

Student 2
When light enters the glass, both f and E decrease, because light loses energy when it collides with atoms of the glass. In addition, vL decreases due to these collisions, so the product f x λ must also decrease. However, λ can either decrease or increase, so long as any increase in λ is not so great as to cause f x λ to increase.

When the light leaves the glass, neither f nor E changes, because there is nothing present in a vacuum that will cause for E to increase. But vL increases to c, the speed of light in a vacuum, so λ must also increase.

Student 3
When light enters the glass, both f and E decrease, because light loses energy when it collides with atoms of the glass. However, vL becomes greater than c due to the gravitational attraction between the glass atoms and the light, so the product f x λ must also increase. Thus, λ must increase, and its increase must be great enough to overcome the decrease in f.

As the light leaves the glass, f and E will have the same values as they had inside the glass, because there is nothing present in a vacuum that will cause f and E to change. However, because of the gravitational attraction between the glass atoms and the light, vL decreases to c, so λ must also decrease.
questions.question: 34. Based on Student 3's predictions, when light enters the glass from the vacuum, which of the properties of light listed below increase (s) in value?I. fII. EIII. vL

questions.question: 35. Based on the information given, when light enters the glass, can light's f change without its E changing?

choices.A: Yes, because the value of h can change.
choices.B: Yes, because the value of h is constant.
choices.C: No, because the value of h can change.
choices.D: No, because the value of h is constant.

However, because of the gravitational attraction between the glass atoms and the light, vL decreases to c, so λ must also decrease.
questions.question: 36. Which students imply that light's frequency before entering the glass is different from its frequency after leaving the glass?

questions.title: Passage Ⅵ
questions.article:
A physics teacher asked 3 students to predict the changes, if any, to light's energy, E; frequency, f(the number of wave peaks passing a given point each second); wavelength, λ (the distance between adjacent peaks of a light wave); and speed, vL, that occur when light travels from a vacuum into clear glass and then from the glass back into the vacuum. The teacher asked the students tobase their predictions on one or both of the following equations:

E = h x f, where h always has the same value

vL = f x λ

Student 1
When light enters the glass, f and E are unchanged. This occurs because light loses no energy when it collides with atoms of the glass. However, vL becomes less than c (the speed of light in a vacuum, 3 x 108 m/sec) due to these collisions, so λ must also decrease.

As the light leaves the glass, both f and E are still unchanged. But upon reentering the vacuum, vL once again becomes c, so λ must increase.

Student 2
When light enters the glass, both f and E decrease, because light loses energy when it collides with atoms of the glass. In addition, vL decreases due to these collisions, so the product f x λ must also decrease. However, λ can either decrease or increase, so long as any increase in λ is not so great as to cause f x λ to increase.

When the light leaves the glass, neither f nor E changes, because there is nothing present in a vacuum that will cause for E to increase. But vL increases to c, the speed of light in a vacuum, so λ must also increase.

Student 3
When light enters the glass, both f and E decrease, because light loses energy when it collides with atoms of the glass. However, vL becomes greater than c due to the gravitational attraction between the glass atoms and the light, so the product f x λ must also increase. Thus, λ must increase, and its increase must be great enough to overcome the decrease in f.

As the light leaves the glass, f and E will have the same values as they had inside the glass, because there is nothing present in a vacuum that will cause f and E to change. However, because of the gravitational attraction between the glass atoms and the light, vL decreases to c, so λ must also decrease.
questions.question: 37. Which of the students, if any, implies that the collisions between light and atoms of the glass cause no change in light's energy?

questions.title: Passage Ⅵ

questions.question: 38.  Which of the students, if any, implies that the speed of light in the vacuum can have more than one value ?

questions.question: 39.  Why does Student 2 maintain that if light enters the glass and λ increases, the size of the increase must be limited? If the increase in λ were too great, the:

choices.C: product f x λ would decrease.
choices.D: product f x λ would increase.

questions.question: 40. If each of Students 1 and 2 were to provide a value for the E of light reentering the vacuum, would Student 1's value be greater than, less than, or equal to Student 2's value ?

choices.D: Cannot be determined from the given information
